title: What problems did Germany have in building an atomic bomb in World War 2? - Quora

response.answer_text: It started at the top with the most senior Nazis describing the whole concept of Atomic Fission as ‘Jewish Science’. Many of the greatest scientists in this field had already fled Germany and mainland Europe for the UK and US, perhaps the original brain drain. Even with sufficient budgets the Axis had no ready supply of Pitchblende/Uraninite and the Norsk hydro plant, a source of Heavy Water, was identified by the Allies very early, attacked both the plant and it’s product. Lastly how would such a weapon have been delivered? Long range heavy bombers never featured in Nazi strategy, even the Condor, four engined maritime aircraft, could carry a weapons load of only 5.5 tonnes externally, or singly, 1 tonne in an internal bomb bay. Insufficient capability to carry any Atomic weapon. So, no support, budget, resources or means of delivery!

I haven’t heard anything about any attempt on their part to create a Hiroshima bomb, by solving the very difficult — at that time — problem of separating uranium-235 out of natural uranium. Instead, they tried to create reactors, but were unsuccessful, although not by much. Had they succeeded, this would have been a big step towards a Nagasaki-style, reactor-fed bomb.

There were a lot of set backs. One was the destruction of the heavy water plant in Norway, another my have been Heisenberg himself.Inside the Daring Mission That Thwarted a Nazi Atomic Bomb andLetter May Solve Nazi A-Bomb Mystery
